Presentation of the SIGPLAN Distinguished Achievement Award to Sir Charles Antony Richard Hoare, FRS, 
FREng, FBCS and Interview Andrew P. Black Peter W. O Hearn Portland State University Queen Mary University 
of London Categories and Subject Descriptors D.2.4 [Software Engineer­ing]: Software/Program Veri.cation; 
D.3.1 [Formal De.nitions and Theory]; F.3.1 [Logics and Meanings of Programs]: Speci­fying and Verifying 
and Reasoning about Programs; F.3.2 [Log­ics and Meanings of Programs]: Semantics of Programming Lan­guages 
General Terms Veri.cation, Reliability, Languages, Theory, Se­curity Award Citation Tony Hoare s long 
career in computing is studded with seminal en­gineering and scienti.c contributions to Programming Languages; 
his views on programming language design have been recognized as profound even by those who declined 
to follow his advice. Two contributions stand out as fundamental: the development of what is now known 
as Hoare logic, and Communicating Sequen­tial Processes. Hoare logic is a system for reasoning about 
impera­tive programs. It was introduced in the 1969 article An Axiomatic Basic for Computer Programming 
, which is perhaps the most in­.uential 6-page paper ever published in CACM. Drawing on ear­lier work 
of Robert Floyd, an entire sub-area of computer science has developed from Hoare s initial ideas; many 
modern veri.cation systems build on Hoare logic. Only 9 years later, CACM published Hoare s paper on 
Com­municating Sequential Processes (CSP). Contemporary with Mil­ner s CCS, but pursuing complementary 
goals, CSP has been enor­mously in.uential. It provided the basis for the occam program­ming language 
and its realization in the Transputer; it has been used for modeling and verifying the concurrency properties 
of critical software systems; and it inspired a .owering of subsequent concur­rency research. Although 
either of these contributions would alone justify the achievement award, Hoare is doing more with his 
Unifying Theo­ries research, which aims to unify theories of programming across paradigm, abstraction 
level and semantic style. Beyond all of this, Tony is renowned for his unfailing courtesy, his inspiration, 
and his dedication to his chosen calling. He is the epitome of a scholar and a gentleman. A Note from 
Peter O Hearn As the POPL program was being planned, following a suggestion from Andy Gordon, the POPL 
PC, ERC, and organizing commit­tees came up with the novel idea of accompanying the presentation of the 
SIGPLAN award with an interview of Tony. When the POPL chairs, John Field and Michael Hicks, approached 
me with this idea and asked if I would consider conducting the interview, I was .lled with delight. Obviously, 
Tony s ideas have in.uenced me enormously. At the beginning of my career I read essentially all of his 
papers cover­ing a wide range of topics including language design, program­ming methodology, and theory. 
The signi.cance and depth of his contributions is plain to see, but in reading his papers something else 
grabbed ahold of me time and again: their marvellous simplic­ity. Many of Hoare s contributions including 
his work on Hoare logic, data types, data abstraction, structured programming, re.ne­ment, monitors, 
CSP and unifying theories seem so natural as to be inevitable, almost obvious ... in retrospect. How 
did he do it? How did he produce so many beautiful, sim­ple ideas? Even though in recent years I have 
gotten to know Tony as a colleague and friend, and learnt a tremendous amount from him, I confess that 
I still don t know. During the interview we will go into Tony s relentless drive towards simplicity, 
his recollections and his hopes, and perhaps a few questions that I don t want him or you to know about 
just yet! Copyright is held by the author/owner(s). POPL 12, January 25 27, 2012, Philadelphia, PA, USA.
